The Student's Predicament

Hyperbolic discounting leads to procrastination.
Example: Doing problem sets...

\caption*{Decisions with Hyperbolic Discounting}
Time Step Commitment Date
$t=0$ $t=1$ "I'll do it tomorrow"
$t=1$ $t=2$ "I'll do it tomorrow"}

Naivete Vs. Sophistication

Extreme assumptions of behavior over time:

Naivete:

An individual who does not realize they will change their mind. That is, they assume their future self will follow through on their (current) preferred plan.

Sophistication:

An individual who understands perfectly that they will change their mind, and does the best given future self's anticipated behavior.

Naivete Vs. Sophistication

How could we tell whether a student is naive or sophisticated?
  • The use of commitment devices indicates sophistication
    • Ulysses is (at least partly) sophisticated.
  • Misprediction of future behavior indicates naivete.
    • Teenage smokers who predict that they will not be smoking in five years have a slightly higher probability of smoking (74%) than those who predict they will be smoking (72%).
(BTW, awareness issues don't arise with exponential discounting.)

Naivete Vs. Sophistication

Behavior of a Naive Student

The naive makes their decision one day at a time. [2exjdsso jdssojdsso jdssojdsso

$t=0$ $-1+\frac{1}{2}\cdot =-1$}

Waiting until $t=2$ is irrational procrastination.

Behavior of a Sophisticated Student

The sophisticate knows exactly what their future selves will do.
  • They solve their own decisions backward...

\emph{Period 0 Self} \emph{Period 1 Self} \emph{Period 2 Self}
$t=0$ $-1+\frac{1}{2}\cdot =-1$}

$t=2$ $0+\frac{1}{2}\cdot =-\frac{5}{4}$} $0+\frac{1}{2}\cdot [-\frac{5}{2}
Predictions of the future leads to doing the problem set at $t=0$.

Let's Go to the Movies

Let's consider a \emph{pleasant} task.
Someone can go to a movie in exactly one of four periods:
\caption*{Assume $\beta=\frac{1}{2}$ and $\delta=1$}
Time $t=0$ $t=1$ $t=2$ $t=3$
Utility $u=1$ $u=\frac{3}{2}$ $u=\frac{9}{4}$ $u=\frac{27}{8}$
When do they go to the movie?

Solving Problems with Hyperbolic Discounting

Naive decision-makers:
  1. Start at the beginning (i.e. first time step).
  2. Solve for the optimal plan at that time step.
    • (Assuming future selves will follow the plan.)
  3. The person takes the first step in that plan.
  4. Go to the next period and repeat.

Solving Problems with Hyperbolic Discounting

Sophisticated decision-makers:
  1. Start at the end (i.e. last time step).
  2. Solve for optimal action.
    • (Assuming the person made it that far.)
  3. Go back to the previous period.
  4. Solve for the optimal action, taking into account what happens in the future.
  5. Go back to the previous period, and repeat.

Going to the Movies: The Naive Person

Going to the Movies: The Sophisticated Person

$u(t)$: $u(0)=1$ $u(1)=\frac{3}{2}$ $u(2)=\frac{9}{4}$ $u(3)=\frac{27}{8}$
Time Step $t=0$ $t=1$ $t=2$ $t=3$
Go in $t=0$ $\frac{16}{16}$ - - -
Go in $t=1$ $\frac{12}{16}$ $\frac{24}{16}$ - -
Go in $t=2$ $\frac{18}{16}$ $\frac{18}{16}$ $\frac{36}{16}$ -
Go in $t=3$ $\frac{27}{16}$ $\frac{27}{16}$ $\frac{27}{16}$ $\frac{54}{16}$
Decision: GO AT $t^*=0$} $t^*=1$} $t^*=2$} $t^*=3$}
This sophisticate wishes they were naive!

The General Lesson

The sophisticated movie-goer's problem is their pessimism.
  • Knows they won't have the patience to wait.
  • So they go immediately.
This pessimism also leads them to do better with problem sets.
Principle:
  • Knowing their future selves will do it tomorrow makes sophisticates more impatient today.
  • Additionally, knowing their future selves will cost them tomorrow warrants taking action today.

So Is It Really Worse to be Sophisticated?}

Theoretically speaking, it's unclear.
Raises a number of concerns:
  • Finishing reports/papers/presentations.
  • Finding good investments for retirement.
  • Quitting bad habits.
  • Finding a job (e.g. for unemployed).

Applications of Hyperbolic Discounting

Default Effects

Madrian and Shea (2001) \emph{Quarterly Journal of Economics}} 401(k) Participation
  • 401(k)s are offered by many employers
    • Primary way employees privately save for retirement.
  • Employees decide themselves whether to participate:
    • How much of their pay to allocate to the 401(k), and
    • How to invest their funds.
  • This company offered a match (up to 6% of income):
    • For every $1 an employee put in their 401(k)
    • The company added 50 cents.
On April 1, 1998, the company changed their 401(k) policy:
  1. Before: could only participate after one year of employment.
    2. After: all employees could enroll.
  2. Before: employees were not automatically enrolled.
    • (Could enroll easily at any time.)
    After: employees were automatically enrolled.
    • (Could unenroll easily at any time.)
The authors compare the choices of two groups of employees:
  1. "Window" cohort: those hired in 1998 before April 1
    • (Not automatically enrolled.)
  2. "New" cohort: those hired in 1998 after April 1
    • (Automatically enrolled.)

Results: Participation and Contribution Rates

3-15 months after being hired, participation rates were:
  • 37% for the Window cohort
  • 86% for the New cohort
The contribution rates were as follows:

The finding that defaults matter is one of the most important discoveries in applied microeconomics.

Getting a Grip on the Default Effect

This appears to be a big mistake by not participating in the 401(k)
  • Being offered a 50% return on up to 6% of your income.
Example: for an employee making $40,000
  • That's giving up a $1,200 gift from the company.
Even if it is not a mistake, why does the default matter so much?
  • It only takes a phone call to change enrollment.
Would people not bother making a phone call for $1,200?
  • If they are naive hyperbolic discounters, they might not.
  • And as a result, defaults can be extremely important.

Making the Call: "I'll do it tomorrow"

Costs and Benefits of Making the Call:
  • Benefit: will get $5 per day ($1,825 per year) extra for the next 30 years starting tomorrow.
  • Cost: pain of the phone call today costs $30
Assume a naive hyperbolic discounter has a daily $\beta = 0.8$, $\delta = 1$.
When to make the call:
  • Today: $-30+0.8\cdot[5\cdot 365\cdot 30] = 43770$
  • Tomorrow: $0+0.8\cdot[-30+5\cdot 365\cdot 30 - 5] = 43772$
Hence, they put off making the phone call.
  • If nothing changes, they put off the phone call forever.

Making the Call: "I'll do it this week (Really, I will)"

This prediction is extreme - and it's because the model is extreme.
  • More reasonable prediction might be they delay for a long time.
Let's change the model:
  • What would a sophisticate do?
  • It's easy to argue they'd do it within a week.
    • Waiting 8 days costs $40, valued at $0.8\cdot 40=32$
    • Would rather pay the $30 cost today to avoid this outcome.
When \emph{exactly} they make the call is a more difficult question.

Other Studies on Procrastination

Choi, et al. (2004) in \emph{NBER}
  • 401(k) contribution patterns generalize.
  • Remarkably similar results across three different industries.
Cronqvist and Thaler (2004) in \emph{American Economic Review}
  • Looks at the privatization of retirement funds in Sweden.
  • Heavily advertised by the government - 456 plans available.
  • Initially, 43.3% of participants chose the default.
  • After 3 years, 91.6% of participants chose the default plan.
Traditional economics: this is due to transaction costs.
  • But actual transaction costs are too small to explain this.

Other Studies on Procrastination (Cont.)

O'Donoghue and Rabin (1999, 2001) in \emph{AER} and \emph{QJE}
  • Self-control problems can explain this behavior.
  • Naivete can create infinite procrastination.
  • Increasing importance makes it more likely you procrastinate.
DellaVigna and Malmendier (2006) in \emph{AER}
  • Study gym-goers' behavior at three US health clubs.
  • Customers had two options for how to pay for using the gym:
    1. Monthly fee of over $80 for unlimited use of the gym.
    2. Pay-per-visit fee of $10.
  • Most choose the monthly contract (89%)
    • Those who do exercise on average 4.8 times/month
    • That's about $17 per visit.
  • \emph{Default Effect:} go 2.31 months (average) without using membership before canceling.
It can be argued these findings are consistent with both extreme assumptions of hyperbolic discounting.
\underline{Naive hyperbolic discounters:}
  • Gym-goers prefer they exercise a lot in the future.
  • Being naive, that's what they think they'll do.
  • To save money on gym they buy the monthly membership.
  • Short-run impatience kicks in, and they don't use the membership much.
\underline{Sophisticated hyperbolic discounters:}
  • Also prefer to exercise a lot in the future, but realize they won't.
  • Use the monthly membership as a commitment tool.
  • Willing to pay more (per-visit) if it helps get them to the gym.

Credit Card Teaser Rates

Ausubel (1991) in \emph{American Economic Review}
  • Large-scale field experiment run by a credit card company.
  • Mailed randomized credit card offers of three types:
    1. Standard: 6.9% rate for six months and 16% thereafter.
    2. Teaser deal: 4.9% followed by 16%.
    3. Post-teaser deal: 6.9% followed by 14%.
  • Data on take-up rates and 21 months of borrowing history.
  • Results:
    • Teaser is 2.5 more successful than Post-teaser
    • Given borrowing history, Post-teaser is a much better deal.

Credit Card Teaser Rates - Explanations

Possible explanations based on hyperbolic discounting:
  1. Naive borrowers believe they'll repay the loan quickly.
    • Hence think the teaser interest rate is the most important.
  2. Sophisticated borrowers don't want to use their credit cards much in the future.
    • Hence choose a high interest rate to restrain future borrowing.
